c4p.brief: GDG DevFest Istanbul was announced, for the sixth year in a row, the conference will bring together 1100 developers, managers and...
c4p.content:
GDG DevFest Istanbul was announced, for the sixth year in a row, the conference will bring together 1100 developers, managers and entrepreneurs on November 4 to Istanbul. This year our team is doing big advancement in the content, we're building an extra stage to accommodate more visitors and provide fife fully independent tracks on Android, Firebase, Machine Learning, Google Cloud and Web topics. Our focus is the content. We’re looking for speakers like you, who are ready to rock the stage and deliver the best talk or workshop in the field.
Submit a proposal
## Why is it cool to speak at the DevFest? DevFest Istanbul is not an ordinary tech conference, besides selecting only the best speakers, we help them to succeed in delivering an exceptional quality talk on the stage. Here are few perks that all our speakers get: - **Expences covered**. Hotel for 2 nights, travel costs and entrance to exclusive dinner after DevFest are covered for all speakers. - **Professional video recording**.We work with experienced video production companies to create session recording of the best quality. Stage, screen, audio, all is recorded separately and combined later. Check the session videos from the last year. - **Exposure**. By being a speaker, you are proving your level of expertise to a potential business partners or employers. Your talk will be promoted in our online resources and recording published in YouTube channel with more than 35k views. - **Unique networking**. Being a speaker means you’ll have the unique chance to network with other speakers - the best experts in the industry. -- **Coaching**. We're in the same boat, after being selected as a speaker our program committee will help you to deliver the best talk possible. We provide information about the audience, presentation templates, feedback on the slides, all to help you to prepare. What are we looking for? We're looking for **experience-based talks**, the information that can not be found in the documentation or easily googled. We're looking for your stories, your struggles, research results and experiences with the frontier tools or technologies. This year we accept submissions in two formats: - 40 minutes sessions. - 2(or 3) hours workshops. ### Talks that will not pass initial review - Talks about a specific tool/library/project explaining how it works or how to use it. - Talks whose focus is pitching a company or project. It’s cool that you mention your company during the presentation, but it shouldn’t be the focus of the talk. - Recruitment talks to attract talent. We strongly recommend you check out speaking.io website from Zach Holman. It includes good tips and guidelines for speakers. ## Timeline **Call for Papers submission deadline is October 14, 2018.** Email organizers at devfest@gdgistanbul.com
Submit a proposal
c4p.title: We're looking for speakers

101.description: In this session, we will take a look at Windows and .NET support on Google Cloud Platform. We will build a simple ASP.NET app, deploy to Google Compute Engine and take a look at some of the tools and APIs available to .NET developers on Google Cloud Platform.
101.title: Windows and .NET on Google Cloud Platform

102.description:
Do you remember the game Simon says from the 80s? I don’t know about you, but I know many that spent hours trying to press those specific sequences of red, green, blue and yellow buttons in the correct order. But why play on your own? We’ve implemented a gRPC server that allows you to play Simon with other players over the internet!

In this workshop we will dive into the toolset and libraries to build your very own Simon Says client for this server. We will have a message description in Protocol Buffers format and some stub code in several languages ready for you to play with. The goal for this workshop is for you to have a working client that you can use to play (and beat!) other attendees of the workshop.
102.title: Hands-on gRPC experience building your own multiplayer game client

103.description:
Doze mode is just around the corner. 
Introduced in Marshmallow, as the shy guy that was allowed to step in only when your device went to sleep. ZzzZzzzz
With the new N release, Doze mode becomes the rockstar. He rushes into the room with a big shabang by shooting all background services and network requests that forgot to get away. 
He should no longer be shy. He just shoots and dances on bones of your scheduled alarms, while you wonder why this particular task is no longer running.
With the new Doze mode, you require to adapt your app architecture to the new reality.
On this talk, we will learn how to survive Doze mode using Job Scheduler, Content Provider and stay in one piece.
103.title: Knock knock! Who's there? Doze.

104.description: It's no longer just about digitizing our environment. It’s rather about pervasive and ubiquitous computing. Almost all everyday things will turn into connected devices soon. This “Internet of Things” will allow the Web to be physically tangible. But what is the value, and how can one prevent IoT applications which just seem to be only more expensive and complicated than conventional solutions. Sascha will discuss the purpose and guide you through this complex topic showing inspiring solutions, tips from practice, and code samples in a variety of technologies from simple Bluetooth Eddystone Beacons to more sophisticated IoT platforms like Eclipse SmartHome.
104.title: The Physical Web: Context is King!

106.description: Fuelio. Success story (I'll write more info later)
106.title: Fuelio. Success story

107.description: There's been much discussion about Progressive Web Apps. They're still a relatively new model. In this talk, I'll summarise few options and techniques for getting started with your own Progressive Web App
107.title: Introduction to Progressive Web Apps in Angular 2

108.description: Angular 2 introduces a new Data Architecture based on Reactive Programming using RxJS 5. We are really excited to see the new approach using Observable sequences aka Observables. We will cover a basic introduction of Angular 2 followed by RxJS 5 and the new HTTP API covering some basic use cases.
108.title: New Data Architecture in Angular 2

109.title: How much money Firebase can save you

110.description: There's a lot of hype around MVP pattern in the Android world. Now it's time for concretes. During his presentation Mateusz will tell you how IG divided responsibilities between pattern's different components, how they tied Presenters' and Views' lifecycles and what they did to make it all testable. If you'd love to make your Fragments' and Activities' code simpler and increase your coverage, but you're confused how to glue it all together - don't miss Mateusz's talk.
110.title: The ultimate guide to MVP pattern on Android

111.description: It's beauty, it's handy, it's fast, it's easy - all about Dagger 2
111.title: Building modular architecture apps with Dagger 2

112.description: Last year brought a lot of new capabilities to browsers, fundamentally changing the way we will build web apps in 2016. 60FPS, push messages, offline support and background sync became a reality marking the birth of Progressive Web Apps.
112.title: Building web apps in 2016

113.description: Microservices is coming with a certain workload and constraints. Let's try to see how Google Cloud Platform and App Engine can help the overall microservices implementation.
113.title: Microservices in Google App Engine

114.description:
Storing account information is a common challenge many app developers face, and is often tackled in tailored solutions. Isn't there some strategy to store account credentials in a centralized place?

What about considerations for multiple accounts? Security concerns? And when should or could I synchronize data?

Android offers a powerful—and underrated—account manager. Let's explore the possibilities together and lay out an architecture for engineering an Android app based on accounts.
114.title: I’ve been doing some syncing…

115.description: Upcoming Android N release will bring some interesting changes to both Android run-time and toolchain. Let's talk about JIT, AOT, hybrid JIT/AOT, Jack, Jill and other acronyms and codenames ;-) In this presentation we'll see how many awesome tricks are needed to make our apps start fast and run smoothly on modern Android devices. Hopefully we'll also answer the most important question -- what's next for Android after Java.
115.title: Android tool-chain and run-time improvements in N

116.description:
One of my favourite things about the web are ASCII smileys. They're sweet, fun and simply make the web a better place. How could anyone not like them ¯(ツ)/¯?

This talk is an overdose of smileys, because they're the perfect excuse to get started with Polymer. Polymer is a library built on top of the Web Components standards that helps developers create reusable components for the modern web. And since I know that everybody has been wondering how one could take over the world by creating a suite of Polymer animated emoticon components, we're going to do exactly that.
116.title: On Polymer and smileys... or Polysmileys

117.description: Data is becoming one of the main decision-makers in an organisation. The more data we have the more challenges we face every day. Every decision we make will have long-term implications. In the talk we will go through different approaches to the data pipelines: from a simple in-house built, with comparison to open source solutions based on Apache stack(Apache Kafka, Apache Samza, Spark) and finally hosted auto-scaling solutions based Amazon(S3, Kinesis, Lambda, EMR) or Google(Pub/Sub, Dataflow, BigQuery). The talk covers the main aspects of data collecting processes altogether with further implications for data processing, highlighting appropriate solutions and architectures for the particular use-cases.
117.title: Building data pipelines: from simple to more advanced - hands-on experience

119.description:
Writing Android apps is usually fun because you are actually building something. But what about writing tests? Boring stuff. Errr, UI tests? I am a developer!

In this talk we will take a look at options for UI tests on Android, why you should write them and how they help you with your app development workflow. No more untested apps!
119.title: Hands-on with UI testing for Android developers

120.description: "Remember back when AJAX completely changed what was possible in the desktop web? Progressive web apps are that same fundamental shift for the mobile web." said Rahul Row-Chowdhury (Google’s product lead for chrome and the web platform) on stage at Google I/O 2016. - Progressive web apps use service workers, app shell, push notifications, RAIL and other capabilities to deliver an app-like user experience.
120.title: Progressive web apps - prepare your web for 2017

121.description: Using service workers and other modern progressive web apps capabilities we can update our web applications to be offline-fires. In this session we'll show how to easily convert your applications be usable without the internet connection.
121.title: Offline-first progressive web apps

122.description: I would like to talk about architecture of our Settle Up app. It's all based on new Firebase announced on I/O with the help of modern frameworks like Rx, Kotlin and MVP.
122.title: Firebase + Kotlin + RxJava + MVP: Practical Tips

124.description: You are tired of building every patch for your QA ? Still deploying to google play manually ? You still think that build server is something that you don't need ? Than I will try to show you how you can make life of your team easier with CI.
124.title: Continues Integration in Android

126.description: Imagine the world where you can get any application, look into its code (even if it is not open sourced) and modify any conditional operator in any way you like. Welcome, you are in the Android applications world! Let's discover how anyone can decompile your app and, for example, hack your 'if' operators. For the beginning, we will play a role of a script kiddie and try to hack some simple app. After this, we will pretend security-conscious Android developers and try to think how we can protect ourselves.
126.title: Android hacking for dummies: ‘if’ operator demolytion

127.description: If you have any experience with Android Media Player, you definitely know how hard it is to prepare it and do not lose your mind. ExoPlayer - is an alternative, which can help you deal with media with much less pain. So lets discuss if it really a "silver bullet" or yet another State Machine hell.
127.title: ExoPlayer: Media playback without pain (almost...)

128.description: Google announced Android Wear 2.0 become available this Fall. This major update brings some revolutionary changes in platform, that should change our approaches in developing wearable apps, including freedom of BLE tethering, system support for complications and activity recognition by GoogleFit, developed mainly for Android Wear 2.0. We will talk deeper about these new features and look at some ways to implement them in the code.
128.title: Android Wear 2.0: Great Changes Upcoming this Fall

129.description:
Accessibility is a very important step to make sure that your app reaches everyone in an easy and fun way to use. 
Good accessibility support means much more than just making sure the app supports screen readers, different fonts sizes and good contrast ratios. It is a learning process, and one in which we ourselves still have much to learn and explore.
129.title: Accessibility on Android

130.description:
Wearable devices are one of the most popular things nowadays. Specially, after the Apple Watch, we finally get the whole picture of the entire list of products and their features. Now, we can talk about how we can design a user experience for this type of devices.
Every platform has it's own design principles and approaches. But, in the core, they all need to follow same core rules. So, how we combine this core requirements with Google's Material Design and use them on an Android Wear device? Let's learn!
130.title: Designing an Android Wear Application

131.description:
In this talk, I will reveal you all the deepest secrets of using MVVM architecture in Android. 
We will discuss on how to organise your application, views, models, how to retrieve data from the model requested from the view via data binding. 
Lightweight Activities and Fragments, is it even possible? 

Yes, and I will show you how to achieve this with MVVM and DataBinding!
131.title: Deal with it: Android DataBinding explained

132.description: Get your badge, coffee, enjoy talking with tech edicts around
132.title: Registration & morning Coffee

136.description: Official start of the conference. Greetings from the organizers, sponsors and partners.
136.title: GDG DevFest Ukraine 2016 Opening

137.description: Afterparty is a great time to have some fun and meet new people
137.title: Afterparty & Networking

138.description: Make sure you won't miss closing ceremony, all gifts from out sponsors and partners will find their owners during this session.
138.title: Conference closing and contest winners announcements

KevinNelson.bio: Kevin Nelson is a Google Cloud Developer Advocate focused on storage and machine learning. Before joining the Cloud team, he was a lead Product Manager on Google Drive. Prior to joining Google in 2014, Kevin was a successful entrepreneur with over 20 years of experience building and managing software and SAAS companies. In addition to working at Google, Kevin sits on the board of Quantum Scientific Imaging, a company he co-founded which designs and manufactures scientific CCD cameras for applications that require superior image performance such as astronomical and medical imaging. In his free time, Kevin is an avid sailor and history buff who loves stargazing and studying the Age of Exploration. Mr. Nelson received a degree in Information and Computer Science from the University of California at Irvine.
KevinNelson.name: Kevin Nelson
KevinNelson.title: Architect Advocate
KevinNelson.shortBio: Kevin Nelson is a Google Cloud Developer Advocate focused on storage and machine learning.

SaidTahsinDane.name: Said Tahsin Dane
SaidTahsinDane.title: Android Lead Engineer
SaidTahsinDane.bio: Expert on Android. Android team lead at Wayfair, Berlin. Very passionate developer who tries to live on the bleeding edge of technology and is very interested in mobile UX.
SaidTahsinDane.shortBio: Expert on Android. Android team lead at Wayfair, Berlin.

MandyChan.name: Mandy Chan Mandy
MandyChan.title: Developer Community Manager
MandyChan.bio: Mandy Chan is the Developer Community Manager on the Actions On Google team, where she is responsible for creating practical content for the developer community. At I/O 2018, Mandy and the team published two Codelabs to guide developers on how to build Actions. Since then, the Codelabs have trained thousands of new developers from around the world. She is a frequent speaker at different developer conferences, including the Grace Hopper Conference in 2017 and 2018. She was recently invited as a guest on the Google Cloud Platform Podcast. You can hear more about her recent activities on http://bit.ly/gcp-mandy. Prior to Google, she made many early contributions to the voice community. One of her most frequently downloaded open source projects is called SSML Builder, which creates well-formed Speech Synthesis Markup Language without worrying about string concatenation. When she is not pondering how to improve the developer experience, you can find her programming, hiking in the mountains, or learning new magic tricks. You can learn more about Mandy by following her on Twitter (@MandyChanNYC)!
MandyChan.shortBio: Mandy Chan is the Developer Community Manager on the Actions On Google team, where she is responsible for creating practical content for the developer community

MeteAtamel.name: Mete Atamel
MeteAtamel.title: Developer Advocate
MeteAtamel.bio: Mete is a Developer Advocate at Google, focused on helping developers with Google Cloud. As a long-time Java and C# developer, he likes to compare the two ecosystems. Prior to Google, he worked at Microsoft, Skype, Adobe, EMC, and Nokia building apps and services on various web, mobile and cloud platforms. Originally from the island of Cyprus, he currently lives in Greenwich of London, not too far away from the prime meridian.
MeteAtamel.shortBio: Mete is a Developer Advocate at Google, focused on helping developers with Google Cloud.

EmilBayazitov.name: Emil Bayazitov
EmilBayazitov.title: Strategic Partnerships, Payments
EmilBayazitov.bio: Extensive product marketing experience at Google (Google Ads, Google Play, Google+), business development in Payments (Google Pay). Currently doing Strategic Partnerships across EMEA for biggest online, offline merchants and transit.
EmilBayazitov.shortBio: Extensive product marketing experience at Google (Google Ads, Google Play, Google+), business development in Payments (Google Pay).

KunalPatel.name: Kunal Patel
KunalPatel.title: Senior Interaction Designer
KunalPatel.bio: Kunal Patel is a Senior Interaction Designer on the Material Design team at Google, focused on navigation, accessible design, and systems outreach. He brings a cross-discipline, design-build methodology to his work thanks to past experiences in architecture and product management.
KunalPatel.shortBio: Kunal Patel is a Senior Interaction Designer on the Material Design team at Google, focused on navigation, accessible design, and systems outreach.

BarisYesugey.bio: As an engineer who is in love with the coolest new technology, I thrive by connecting to other developers who share similar passions. My team is behind all the rich, technical content on developers.google.com.  I act as an advocate for third party developers’ needs within Google and passionate evangelists for Google technologies in the outside world. I love connecting with other developers and partners; people who enjoy teaching, speaking or writing about cutting-edge technologies. By working closely with third party developers who are building applications and businesses that showcase Google’s developer platforms, I grow and support the developer community, teaching and supporting developers around MENA region.
BarisYesugey.name: Barış Yesugey
BarisYesugey.shortBio: As an engineer who is in love with the coolest new technology, I thrive by connecting to other developers who...

Doç.Dr.MehmetAydın.bio: Mehmet N. Aydin, Associate Professor at Management Information Systems Department and the director of INEO Technology Transfer Office at Kadir Has University, Istanbul has provided organizations with proven expertise in the emerging field of cloud computing, Corporate Innovations Systems and Technology Management, Network Science. He holds PhD in Management Information Systems from University of Twente, The Netherlands. Dr. Aydin worked at the Institute for Innovation and Technology Management, Ryerson University, Toronto, Canada and at the Department of Information Systems and Change Management at University of Twente, the Netherlands. He has published over 50 articles as journal papers (e.g., Journal of Database Management, Information Frontiers, Journal of Enterprise Management), book chapters (e.g., Springer series on Lecture Notes in Computer Science) conference proceedings (IFIP 8.1, CAISE). His contribution to the research field of method engineering is laudable and cited in various studies. He can be reached at mehmet.aydin@khas.edu.tr.
Doç.Dr.MehmetAydın.name: Doç. Dr. Mehmet Aydın
Doç.Dr.MehmetAydın.shortBio: Mehmet N. Aydin, Associate Professor at Management Information Systems Department and the director of INEO Technology Transfer Office...

BurcuYalcinkaya.bio: Burcu graduated from Department of Computer Engineering at Anadolu University, Eskişehir in 2012. She started Android development out of curiosity, and still haven't lost her excitement to this day. Aside from Android, she's also quite familiar with the iOS platform. She worked in fields such as hospital automation, farm management and banking. She is an organizer of WTM and GDG İstanbul. She loves giving tech talks and making other people love the Android platform. Her hobbies include organizing hackathons, participating in them and travelling to new places.

Since four years with General Mobile as Software Director, He manages high skilled software teams with tens of successful project stories.

After attending Google I/O 2016 he has been carried away with learning Firebase.

I work on the Android app and helped build the REST Api for the platform. </br> Beside making awesome Apps I help manage the technical part of the food blog Betty’s Kitchen which is run by my wife  which has about 80/90k visitors per month

Passionate about good UX, IoT and Android.</br>Previously he worked in a publication company on digital magazines. Today, he works at t-mob, Turkey's leading mobile development agency in Istanbul making and creating apps that users love.</br>Caner has been a user group leader at GDG Istanbul since 2013, organizing, participating, and speaking at events. He shares his experience in User Experience via conferences or workshops at Droidcon, DevFest, and other conferences.

She blogs in her native language at her blog(elifboncuk.com) about everything but mostly tech and also at Medium in English and only tech.</br>In addition, she loves to travel and she is a professional photographer but her favourite photography object is Android sculpture. You can find her taking photos with Androids at any time.

Serhat Atayeter.bio: Serhat Atayeter has been graduated from Information Systems and Technologies as well as International Business and Trade departments. He holds MBA degree from Koc University. He was the co-founder of el6 (an ad-hoc social network) before joining Google in 2011. He worked as Account Strategist in travel vertical at Google until 2013 before he's joined Customer Solution and Innovation team as Performance Marketing Consultant. He also teaches Data-driven Decision Making course at Bogazici University as part-time lecturer.

She always tries to go beyond the day to day life and learn something new, for now is interested a lot in Machine Learning.</br>Despite that, Sofia is a manager of GDG Lviv and also leads local WTM community in Lviv. Additionally, one of organisers of GDG DevFest Ukraine (https://devfest.gdg.org.ua/).

He is very visible in public conferences and organizer of Android Istanbul, also active member of GDG Istanbul. He is also blogging about android technologies and trends weekly, also love to share his experiences as open source library at github.com. In his quiet time, he loves to draw and travel.

İbrahim Kıvanç.bio: Ibrahim KIVANC is Software Development Engineer at Microsoft, CSE (Commerical Software Engineering) delivers programs ensuring latest Microsoft technologies and platforms are accessible and implemented. Prior to this role he was responsible for Middle East and Africa HQ over 4 years. After that worked in Microsoft Turkey for 2 years and now he's covering Microsoft Middle East region. He is responsible with the latest development technologies at Microsoft.</br>Ibrahim received his bachelor' degree in Computer Engineering and holds a master's degree in Management and Infromation System with his thesis on 'Cross Platform Development Strategies for Enterprise Companies' . He's also a former Microsoft Student Partner and winner of Imagine Cup in Turkey, represented Turkey in World Wide Finals in Poland 2010.</br>His major skills are based on Cross Platform Development tools for Android, iOS and Windows, Xbox One Development, IoT, Office Apps, Chat Bots, Cognitive Services and Unity.

Georgia Ingham.bio: Georgia Ingham is a Java developer at IDRsolutions where she works on the Java PDF library and PDF to HTML5/SVG converters. Georgia has spoken twice at JavaOne and organised a NetBeans conference in the UK. She is really looking forward to her very first DevFest and trip to Turkey with the chance to share her enthusiasm for NetBeans, meet lots of new people, see the sites and say hello to the cats in Istanbul.
Georgia Ingham.name: Georgia Ingham
Georgia Ingham.shortBio: Georgia Ingham is a Java developer at IDRsolutions where she works on the Java PDF library and PDF to HTML5/SVG converters. Georgia has spoken twice at JavaOne and organised a NetBeans ...
Georgia Ingham.title: Developer

Mark Stephens.bio: Mark Stephens was a speaker at DevFest 13,14, and 15. He has been working with Java since 1997 and PDF since 1999. He is an Entrepreneur and software developer who setup his own company in 1999. IDRsolutions develops a Java PDF library and a PDF to HTML5/SVG converter. He is a keen NetBeans user and helps to organise NetBeans UK conference. Mark has an MSC degree in Computer Science and an MA in Mediaeval History with a detailed knowledge of Byzantine and Ottoman History. So DevFest is his dream conference as he can combine software and coding with palaces, churches, mosques and cisterns.
Mark Stephens.name: Mark Stephens
Mark Stephens.shortBio: Mark Stephens was a speaker at DevFest 13,14, and 15. He has been working with Java since 1997 and PDF since 1999. He is an Entrepreneur and software developer who setup his own company ...

GürayYıldırım.bio: Graduated from Istanbul Technical University, Electronic and Communication Engineering. Worked as a embedded system engineer, GNU/Linux system administrator, software engineering analyst and research assistant.Author of two books, Raspberry Pi & IoT Applications with Raspberry Pi and Python.I have been using Docker Swarm mode with Docker Stack and CLI in some cases. I have been writing a book about Docker and container technology which will be published in a couple of weeks. I have given some talks about Docker which includes but not limited to Monitoring IoT Systems with Docker Swarm, Grafana and Telegraf, Raspberry Pi Cluster with Docker Swarm, Storage Options with Docker CE and Docker EE, Dockerizing Applications, Dockerfile Best Practices, Security with Docker, Docker for Developers, Introduction to Docker and Containers. I have been deployed Docker for e-commerce, monitoring, personal blog websites etc. I am running docker on GNU/Linux (Fedora, Ubuntu, Raspbian) and Mac OS. I have also given some workshops with play-with-docker and Portainer.
GürayYıldırım.name: Güray Yıldırım

GürayYıldırım.title: Siber Güvenlik Araştırmacısı

RobertoOrgiu.bio: Born in Italy in 1987, passionate for everything that switches on and off and particularly for handheld and wearable devices. I love to learn new languages such as Kotlin, patterns and everything Android-related. I recently joined The New York Times Android team as Android Engineer.

Lemi Orhan Ergin.bio:
Lemi Orhan Ergin has been working as Agile Software Craftsman and Agile Practice Lead at iyzico. He completed his undergraduate and graduate degree in Computer Engineering department of Marmara University. He has been actively developing software since 2001. He has worked as software architect, software craftsman, technical leader, team leader, technical coordinator, Scrum Master and Agile coach in dozens of software projects at BYM, GittiGidiyor / eBay and Sony. As a managing partner in ACM, he has provided consulting services to dozens of companies. He has led the establishment of agile software cultures, continuity and sustainability in software teams.

He has been sharing his experience about Agile / Scrum, Kanban, Management 3.0, Git, ALM Processes, TDD, Clean Code, Agile Engineering Practices and Software Craftsmanship with hundreds of professionals. He has been a national and international conference speaker. Slides of his talks has been displayed more than 1 million times on the Internet.

He works voluntarily in software communities. He is the founder of the Software Craftsmanship Turkey community. He had been the leader of the community and the product owner of Agile Turkey Summit and CraftSummit conferences for two years.

Can Ali Avunduk.bio: Can Ali Avunduk works on digital platforms and fintech since 2008. Prior to his work at Google, Mr. Avunduk was in charge of Garanti Bank's products and services running on mobile platforms. Before he joined Garanti, he was working at 3pay.com, Turkey's first mobile payment start-up, now a Wirecard company. Mr. Avunduk received his B.Sc. Degree from Bilkent University with a major in Industrial Engineering and his M.Sc. degree from Bogazici University's Engineering and Technology Management program.

Armağan Amcalar.bio: Armagan is the Head of Software Engineering at unu GmbH, and is currently working on building the infrastucture for the future of mobility. A software architect well versed in both the backend and frontend systems, he focuses on building resilient clouds. He loves open source and is the author of cote, a library for building microservices with Node.js. He spends most of his free time teaching JavaScript as a university lecturer, a consultant or NGO worker. He also leads Lonca Works, a software craftsmanship guild.

Yalçın Yenigün.bio: Actually I develop a real-time fraud detection product at iyzico to detect credit card fraud with machine learning and artificial intelligence. I am also a master science student at Galatasaray University Computer Engineering Department in machine learning area. Previously I worked for ZeroBuffer, Vodafone and Bilge Adam as a software engineer. I am also a reviewer of a book named 'Appium Essentials' on mobile test automation.

Erdem Demir.bio: Erdem Demir is a a software engineer and technical consultant.  Erdem holds a PhD from University of California in Software Engineering, he has over 10 years of experience in building complex software systems and technical consulting.  He worked as a Software Engineer for Google from 2007 to 2011, worked as a Software Architect for Ericsson between 2011 and 2013, and has been working as a Publishers Technical Consultant with Google since 2013.

He holds a PhD from Boğaziçi University in Computer Science and has 10+ years of experience in designing, developing and delivering telecommunications, mobile and web solutions. KaanMamikoglu.bio: Kaan is a mobile software engineer at MyDrive Solutions in London, UK. As an active community builder, he has co-organized a lot of developer events in Turkey and the UK such as DevFests, Android Developer Days’, Android Study Jams, etc. Besides being a Google Developer Group (GDG) London co-organizer, he is a Google Top Contributor (TC) and a Google Local Guide. Kaan is passionate about exploring new technologies and traveling around the world.
